Series Solutions to Differential Equations

Up until this point, we've made many advances on the topic of linear differential equations. We now have a systematic method to determine the solutions of a constant-coefficient DE completely. Using various methods like the Wronskian, Abel's theorem, and variation of parameters, we can even determine particular solutions to any second-order linear DE. But what if the homogeneous equation we are considering does not have constant coefficients - for instance, equations like:

4x3y′′−(x2+1)y′+xy=04x^3y'' - (x^2+1)y' + xy = 04x3y′′−(x2+1)y′+xy=0

For differential equations which do not have particularly "nice" (elementary) solutions, power series solutions are the best we can hope for - that is, solutions in the form

y=∑n=0∞cnxny=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n x^ny=n=0∑∞​cn​xn

(or, equivalently, cn(x−x0)nc_n (x-x_0)^ncn​(x−x0​)n), for finite coefficients c0,c1,…c_0, c_1, \dotsc0​,c1​,…, under the assumption that such a power series will converge.

Before we begin our study of power series solutions to differential equations, we need to lay out a few basic principles regarding power series: namely, the notions of convergence/absolute convergence/divergence, the concept of the radius of convergence, and the application of the ratio test.

Definition. (Convergence, absolute convergence, and divergence.) The power series

y=∑n=0∞cn(x−x0)ny=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n (x-x_0)^ny=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−x0​)n

is said to converge at a point xxx if the limit

lim⁡k→∞∑n=0kcn(x−x0)n\lim_{k\to\infty}\sum_{n=0}^{k} c_n (x-x_0)^nk→∞lim​n=0∑k​cn​(x−x0​)n

exists; conversely, if the limit diverges to infinity, the power series is said to diverge.

The power series is said to absolutely converge at a point xxx if the sum of the absolute value of all its terms

lim⁡k→∞∑n=0k∣cn(x−x0)n∣\lim_{k\to\infty}\sum_{n=0}^{k} |c_n (x-x_0)^n|k→∞lim​n=0∑k​∣cn​(x−x0​)n∣

also converges. If a series is absolutely convergent at xxx, then it is also regularly convergent at xxx, though the converse is not necessarily true.

There is a non-negative number ρ\rhoρ such that, for all ∣x−x0∣<ρ|x-x_0|<\rho∣x−x0​∣<ρ, the series converges absolutely, and for all ∣x−x0∣>ρ|x-x_0|>\rho∣x−x0​∣>ρ, it diverges. Call ρ\rhoρ the radius of convergence.

To determine the convergence of a power series, we can apply

Method (Ratio test). For a fixed value of xxx and for an≠0a_n\neq 0an​=0, consider the limit of the ratio between two consecutive terms:

lim⁡n→∞∣cn+1(x−x0)n+1cn(x−x0)n∣=lim⁡n→∞∣x−x0∣∣cn+1cn∣=lim⁡n→∞∣x−x0∣L\lim_{n\to\infty} |\frac{c_{n+1}(x-x_0)^{n+1}}{c_{n}(x-x_0)^n}|=\lim_{n\to\infty} |x-x_0||\frac{c_{n+1}}{c_n}|=\lim_{n\to\infty}|x-x_0|Ln→∞lim​∣cn​(x−x0​)ncn+1​(x−x0​)n+1​∣=n→∞lim​∣x−x0​∣∣cn​cn+1​​∣=n→∞lim​∣x−x0​∣L

If this ratio is less than 1, the terms of the power series are shrinking and the series converges absolutely; if it is greater than 1, the terms are increasing and thus the series diverges. If the ratio is 1, then no conclusive statement can be made.

For a convergent power series, taking its derivative is equivalent to adding up the derivatives of all of its terms; that is,

y′=∑n=0∞(cn(x−x0)n)′     (=∑n=0∞ncn(x−x0)n−1)y'=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (c_n (x-x_0)^n)'\ \ \ \ \ (=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} nc_n (x-x_0)^{n-1})y′=n=0∑∞​(cn​(x−x0​)n)′     (=n=0∑∞​ncn​(x−x0​)n−1)

implying that yyy is infinitely differentiable at x0x_0x0​. If yyy indeed has a power series representation at x=x0x=x_0x=x0​, we refer to yyy as analytic. This gives us everything we need to establish two more important classifications: ordinary and singular points. Let us return to the general form of our second-order linear DE:

p(x)y′′+q(x)y′+r(x)y=0p(x)y''+q(x)y'+r(x)y=0p(x)y′′+q(x)y′+r(x)y=0

which can also be written as

y′′+q(x)p(x)y′+r(x)p(x)y=0y''+\frac{q(x)}{p(x)}y'+\frac{r(x)}{p(x)}y=0y′′+p(x)q(x)​y′+p(x)r(x)​y=0
